question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system, given the values of the parameters $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
-x &- &4y &- &4z &= &\alpha \\ 
x &- &3y &- &z &= &\beta \\ 
2x &+ &4y &+ &z &= &\gamma
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{-\alpha+12\beta+8\gamma}{29},\,\frac{3\alpha-7\beta+5\gamma}{29},\,\frac{-10\alpha+4\beta-7\gamma}{29}\right)$.
answer2: The system has no solution for $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=0$, and for all other choices of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution which is $\left(\alpha+3\beta-\gamma,\,\gamma,\,\beta-\gamma\right)$.
answer3: The sistem has no solutions for every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$, the system has infinite solutions, which are $\left(\alpha-\beta+\gamma+z,\,1+z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

-2x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
x & - & 3y & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a \neq 1$ and $b \neq -1$.

The system has no solution if $a\neq 1$ and $b\neq 1$.

Find the general solution for the differential equation system

$\begin{cases}
x'(t)=2x+y \\
y'(t)=x+3y-z \\
z'(t)=-x+2y+3z
\end{cases}$
answer3:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{3t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(3\cos (t)-\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+2C_{2}e^{3t}\cos t+3C_{3}e^{3t}\sin t,
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{t}(\cos (t)-3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(3\cos (t)+\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+5C_{2}e^{t}\cos (t)+5C_{3}e^{t}\sin (t),
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.

question:

$$\begin{cases}
x &- &y &+ &z &+ &2t &= &2 \\

\end{cases}$$

answer3: The system has $\left(1-2z,\,-1-z,\,z,\,0\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

\end{cases}$$

answer2: The system has no solution for $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=0$, and for all other choices of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution which is $\left(\alpha+3\beta-\gamma,\,\gamma,\,\beta-\gamma\right)$.

Find the solution of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &0 \\ 
&3x &- &y &- &5z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer3:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$(3+z,2-2z,z),\, \forall z\in \mathbb{R}$$.
answer4:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameter:
$$(3+z+y,y,z),\, \forall y,z\in \mathbb{R}$$.

answer2: There are $1$ local minimum and $1$ saddle point.
answer3: There are $1$ local maximum and $1$ local minimum.

question:
A distribution company owns two warehouses (i) in the south of the country (W1 and W2). From these points, the company needs to supply its customers (j) in four cities, C1, C2, C3  and C4 (one customer per city). The transport cost for each tonne of material is 100 u.m./km. The following table shows the distances to be traveled between the two warehouses and the various cities (in km):

	\[
\begin{array}{l|cccc|}
& C_1 & C_2 & C_3  &  C_4\\
\hline
W_1 & 100 & 85 & 270  & 500 \\
W_2 & -  & 185 & 185 & 150\\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

The requirements of customers C1, C2, C3 and C4 are respectively 200, 250, 400 and 150 tonnes. The inventory in both warehouses W1 and W2 is 200 and 500 tonnes, respectively. The company has established agreements with the various customers, setting the following prices to charge (u.m./ton):

	\[
\begin{array}{l|cccc|}
& C_1 & C_2 & C_3  &  C_4\\
\hline
W_1 & 10500  & 9250 & 27570  & 50870\\
W_2 & - & 19150 & 18600 & 15220\\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

Determine the optimal solution, formulating a transport problem.

The Omega Manufacturing Company has discontinued the production of a certain unprofitable product line. This act created considerable excess production capacity. Management is considering devoting this excess capacity to one or more of three products; call them products 1, 2, and 3. The available capacity on the machines that might limit output is summarized in the following table:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|c|c|}
	\hline
	\text{Machine Type} & \text{Available Time (machine hours per week)} \\
	\hline
	\text{Milling machine} & 500 \\
	\text{Lathe} & 350 \\
	\text{Grinder} & 150 \\
	\hline
	\end{array}\]
		
The number of machine hours required for each unit for a given product is the following:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
	\hline
	\text{Machine Type} & \text{Product 1} & \text{Product 2} & \text{Product 3} \\
	\hline
	\text{Milling machine} & 9 & 3 & 5 \\
	\text{Lathe} & 5 & 4 & 0 \\
	\text{Grinder} & 3 & 0 & 2 \\
	\hline
	\end{array}\]

\end{cases}$$

Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & 2z & - & 3t & = & 1 \\ 
2x & + & y & - & 2z & - & t & = & 2 \\ 
x &- &3y &+ &z &- &2t &= &-1 \\
  &   &      &     &z &- &t &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(5,\,1,\,3,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(5+20y,\,y,\,-10-13y,\,8+15y\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(5,0,-10,8\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & - & 4z & = & 2 \\ 
-x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\ 
x & + & 5y & - & 5z & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(\frac{1}{3}+\frac{5}{3}z,\,\frac{4}{3}+\frac{2}{3}z,\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has two solutions: $\left(1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ and $\left(0,\,2,\,-1\right)$.

question:
Consider the linear applications 

$\begin{array}{cccc}
F: & \mathbb{R}^3 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y, z) & \longrightarrow & (y, x-z)
\end{array}$
$\begin{array}{cccc}
G: & \mathbb{R}^2 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y) & \longrightarrow & (x+y, x-2y)
\end{array}$

Choose the right answer:
answer1: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)$ does not exist
answer2: $(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$and $(G\circ F)$ does not exist
answer3: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$
answer4: $(G\circ F)(y, x-z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)(x, y)=(x+y, x-2y)$

A consulting firm will carry out two types of projects ($A$ and $B$). The development cost per project $A$ and $B$ is, respectively, $1$ and $2$ monetary units. The requirements in terms of analysts, programmers and terminals for each type of project are indicated in the following table:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Project} & \text{N. of programmers}  & \text{N. of analysts}  & \text{N. of terminals} \\
\hline
\text{A} & 2 & 2 & 3 \\
\text{B} & 3 & 6 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

The company wants to minimize the cost of developing projects in the next period. In the development of these projects, at least $10$ programmers and $5$ analysts should be used while the company only has $6$ terminals available. How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized  to allow planning the company's activity?

The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.

How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning of the company's activity?
answer1:
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
	        & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			& x_{2}\leq 60\\
			&  x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
			    & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\leq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
    			& 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\geq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]

A researcher studies the wind speed in a particular city. A sample of two hundred observations was recorded. The mean speed was calculated to be $10 m/s$ and the median speed was calculated to be $7 m/s$. Which of the following interpretations is correct?
answer1: $50\%$ of the sampled observations had speed that was less than or equal to $7 m/s$.
answer2: The most frequently occurring wind speed in the sample was $7 m/s$.
answer3: $50\%$ of the sampled observations had speed that was equal to $7 m/s$.
answer4: $50\%$ of the sampled observations had speed that was less than or equal to $10 m/s$.

question: Differentiate $y(x)=\displaystyle{(4-x^3)e^{5x}}$.

For each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, describe the solutions of the linear system
$$\begin{cases}
3x & + & y & - & z & = & 1 \\
x & - & 2y & - & z & = & m \\
x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
For $m=-2$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m \neq -2$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer2: The linear system has no solution for every $m\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
For $m \in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m=0$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(0,\,1,\,1\right)$.
For $m \not\in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has a unique solution for each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, which is $\left(0,\,m,\,m-1\right)$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
3x & - & y & - & 2z & = & a \\
-x & + & 3y & - & z & = & b \\
-2x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
x & - & 3y & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a \neq 1$ and $b \neq -1$.
If $a=1$ and $b=-1$, then the system has $\left(\frac{2+7z}{8},\,\frac{-2+5z}{8},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,1,\,0\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4:
The system has no solution if $a\neq 1$ and $b\neq 1$. 
If $a=b=1$, the system has $\left(1+y,\,y,\,\frac{3+y}{4}\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

answer4:

Let $H=\left\{\left[\begin{array}{rr}
      a & b \\
	 0 & a^2
			\end{array}\right]: a,b \in \mathbb{R}\right\}$. Choose the right answer.
answer1:
$H$ is not a subspace of $M_{2\times 2}(\mathbb{R})$ because $\left[\begin{array}{rr}
      3 & 2 \\
	 0 & 9
			\end{array}\right] + \left[\begin{array}{rr}
      1 & 0 \\
	 0 & 1
			\end{array}\right] \notin H$
answer2:
$H$ is a subspace of $M_{2\times 2}(\mathbb{R})$ because $\left[\begin{array}{rr}
      0 & 0 \\
	 0 & 0
			\end{array}\right] \in H$
answer3:
Since $ 1\times\left[\begin{array}{rr}
      a & b \\
	 0 & a^2
			\end{array}\right] \in H$, than $H$ is a subspace of $M_{2\times 2}(\mathbb{R})$
answer4:
$H$ is not a  subspace of $M_{2\times 2}(\mathbb{R})$ because $\left[\begin{array}{rr}
      2 & 0 \\
	 0 & 6
			\end{array}\right] + \left[\begin{array}{rr}
      1 & 0 \\
	 0 & 1
			\end{array}\right] \notin H$

question: Differentiate $f(x) = 2\operatorname{sin}(3x) - 5\operatorname{cos}(2x)$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
 &  & ay & + & az & = & ab \\ 
 &  &  &  & bz & = & a \\ 
x & + & y & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
If $a=b=0$, the system has $\left(x,\,y,\,1-x-y\right)$ as solution for every $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.
If $a=0$ and $b\neq 0$, the system has $\left(x,\,1-x,\,0\right)$ as solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
If $a\neq 0$ and $b=0$, the system has no solutions. 
If $a,b\neq 0$, the system has $\left(1-b,\,\frac{b^{2}-a}{b},\,\frac{a}{b}\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer2:
The system has no solutions for $a\neq b$. 
If $a=b=0$, the system has $\left(x,\,y,\,1-x-y\right)$ as its solution for every $x,y\in\mathbb{R})$. 
If $a=b\neq 0$, the system has $\left(x,\,1-x,\,0\right)$ as its solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(b-a,\,b^{2}-a,\,\frac{b^{2}-a}{2a^{2}+1}\right)$ as its unique solution for every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
If $a=b=0$, the system has $\left(x,\,y,\,1-x-y\right)$ as its solution for every $x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{2}$. 
If $a=0$ and $b\neq 0$, the system has no solutions.
If $a\neq 0$ and $b=0$, the system has $\left(x,\,0,\,x\right)$ as its solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
If $a,b\neq 0$, the system has $\left(x+a,\,y-\frac{b}{a},\,1-ax-by\right)$ as its solution for every $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

answer1: The problem has the minimizer $\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right),$ the minimum value of the function being $-\frac{1}{2}.$
answer2: There are two minimizers $\left(\frac{1}{4}, \frac{3}{4}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{3}{4},\frac{1}{4}\right)$ where the minimum value of the function is $-\frac{3}{8}.$
answer3: There are two maximizers $\left(\frac{2}{5}, \frac{3}{5}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{3}{5},\frac{2}{5}\right)$ where the maximum value of the function is $-\frac{12}{25}.$
answer4: The problem has no extrema corresponding to this constraint.

\end{cases}$$

answer3: The system has $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},-\frac{7}{12},-\frac{3}{4},0\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer4: The solution of the system is the vector of coordinates $(2,-1,0,0)$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system, given the values of the parameters $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
-x &- &4y &- &4z &= &\alpha \\ 
x &- &3y &- &z &= &\beta \\ 
2x &+ &4y &+ &z &= &\gamma
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{-\alpha+12\beta+8\gamma}{29},\,\frac{3\alpha-7\beta+5\gamma}{29},\,\frac{-10\alpha+4\beta-7\gamma}{29}\right)$.
answer2: The system has no solution for $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=0$, and for all other choices of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution which is $\left(\alpha+3\beta-\gamma,\,\gamma,\,\beta-\gamma\right)$.
answer3: The sistem has no solutions for every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$, the system has infinite solutions, which are $\left(\alpha-\beta+\gamma+z,\,1+z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components.

\]

Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & 2z & = & 2 \\
3x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
-x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(-1,\,3,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has two solutions, $\left(-1,\,3,\,3\right)$ and $\left(2,\,1,\,0\right)$.
answer4: The system has an infinite number of solutions, which are of the form $\left(-4+z,\,z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

answer1: The lines $r$ and $s$ are equal if $m=-2$, parallel if $m=2$, and secant otherwise.
answer2: The lines $r$ and $s$ are equal if $m=2$, parallel if $m=-2$, and secant otherwise.
answer3: The lines $r$ and $s$ are secant for every $m$.
answer4: The lines $r$ and $s$ are parallel for every $m$.

Find the domain, the image and the continuity points set of the function
$$f(x,y)=\begin{cases}
\frac{2-\sqrt{4-x^2-y^2}}{x^2+y^2} & \text{if } (x,y) \neq (0,0) \\
\frac{1}{4} & \text{if } (x,y) = (0,0)
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The domain is $D=\left\{(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid x^2+ y^2 \leq 4\right\}$, the image is $\left[\displaystyle\frac{1}{4},\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\right]$ and $f$ is continuous on $D$.
answer2: The domain is $D=\left\{(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid  x^2+ y^2 \leq 4\right\}$, the image is $\left[\displaystyle\frac{1}{4},2\right]$ and $f$ is continuous on $D$.
answer3: The domain is $D=\left\{(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid  x^2+ y^2 \leq 4\right\}$, the image is $\left[\displaystyle\frac{1}{4},\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\right]$ and $f$ is continuous on $D\setminus\{(0,0)\}$.
answer4: The domain is $D=\left\{(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid  x^2+ y^2 \leq 4\right\}$, the image is $\left[\displaystyle\frac{1}{4},2\right]$ and $f$ is continuous on $D\setminus\{(0,0)\}$.

Find the general solution for the differential equation system

$\begin{cases}
x'(t)=2x+y \\
y'(t)=x+3y-z \\
z'(t)=-x+2y+3z
\end{cases}$
answer3:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{3t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(3\cos (t)-\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+2C_{2}e^{3t}\cos t+3C_{3}e^{3t}\sin t,
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{t}(\cos (t)-3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(3\cos (t)+\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+5C_{2}e^{t}\cos (t)+5C_{3}e^{t}\sin (t),
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.

question: Find the conditional extrema of the function $f(x,y)=x^2+y^2-x-y$ having the constraint $x+y=1.$
answer1: The problem has the minimizer $\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right),$ the minimum value of the function being $-\frac{1}{2}.$
answer2: There are two minimizers $\left(\frac{1}{4}, \frac{3}{4}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{3}{4},\frac{1}{4}\right)$ where the minimum value of the function is $-\frac{3}{8}.$
answer3: There are two maximizers $\left(\frac{2}{5}, \frac{3}{5}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{3}{5},\frac{2}{5}\right)$ where the maximum value of the function is $-\frac{12}{25}.$
answer4: The problem has no extrema corresponding to this constraint.

question:
Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{C}^2\right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
(1+i)z& + & (1-i)w & = & i \\
(1-i)z& + & (1+i)w & = & 1-i
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The unique solution of the linear system is $\bigg(\frac{3+i}{4},-\frac{1+i}{4}\bigg)$.
answer2: The solutions of the linear system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{1+i}{4},\frac{-1+i}{4}+z\bigg)$, for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has the vector $(i,-i)$ has its unique solution.

  &   &      &     &z &- &t &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(5,\,1,\,3,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(5+20y,\,y,\,-10-13y,\,8+15y\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(5,0,-10,8\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & 2z & = & 2 \\
3x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
-x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(-1,\,3,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has two solutions, $\left(-1,\,3,\,3\right)$ and $\left(2,\,1,\,0\right)$.
answer4: The system has an infinite number of solutions, which are of the form $\left(-4+z,\,z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

Consider the real function $f:\mathbb{R}\longrightarrow\mathbb{R}$ defined by $f(x):=2x^{2}-6x+5$. Find all real numbers $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(x)=ax+bx(x-1)+c(x-1)(x-2)$$for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer1: The only possible choice is $a=1$, $b=-\frac{1}{2}$ and $c=\frac{5}{2}$.
answer3: A solution of the problem is given by any $a\in\mathbb{R}$ and by $b=a-3$ and $c=1-a$.
answer4: The only possible solution is given by $a=1$, $b=0$ and $c=-2$.

question: Find the differentiable function $f$ such that $\nabla f(x,y)=(4x^{3}y^{3}-3x^{2})\vec{i}+(3x^{4}y^{2}+\cos (2y))\vec{j},$ for each $(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^{2}.$
answer1: $f(x,y)=x^{4}y^{3}-x^{3}+\frac{1}{2}\sin (2y)+C,$ for each $(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^{2},$ where $C$ is an arbitrary constant;
answer2: $f(x,y)=x^{4}y^{3}-x^{3}-\frac{1}{2}\sin (2y)-C,$ for each $(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^{2},$ where $C$ is an arbitrary constant;
answer3: $f(x,y)=x^{4}y^{3}-x^{3}+\cos (2y)+C,$ for each $(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^{2},$ where $C$ is an arbitrary constant;
answer4: $f(x,y)=4x^{3}y^{3}-x^{3}+\frac{1}{2}\cos (2y)+C,$ for each $(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^{2},$ where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

question:
Find the solution of the following system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &-1 \\ 
&x &+ &y &- &5z &= &2
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3},y, -\frac{1}{3}\right),\, \forall y\in\mathbb{R}$$.
answer2:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3}z,y, z\right),\, \forall y,z\in\mathbb{R}$$.

2x & - & y & - & z & + & t & = & 0 \\
x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},\frac{1}{4}t-\frac{7}{12},\frac{3}{4}t-\frac{3}{4},t\bigg)$, for all $t\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:

$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & + & w & = & -2 \\
3x & - & y & - & 2z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
x & + & y & - & z & + & w & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x+y,\,x-y-1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system, given the values of the parameters $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
-x &- &4y &- &4z &= &\alpha \\ 
x &- &3y &- &z &= &\beta \\ 
2x &+ &4y &+ &z &= &\gamma
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{-\alpha+12\beta+8\gamma}{29},\,\frac{3\alpha-7\beta+5\gamma}{29},\,\frac{-10\alpha+4\beta-7\gamma}{29}\right)$.
answer2: The system has no solution for $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=0$, and for all other choices of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution which is $\left(\alpha+3\beta-\gamma,\,\gamma,\,\beta-\gamma\right)$.
answer3: The sistem has no solutions for every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$, the system has infinite solutions, which are $\left(\alpha-\beta+\gamma+z,\,1+z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:

x & + & 2y & - & 3z & + & w & = & -2 \\

2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
4x & + & y & - & 5z & - & 3w & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x-y,\,x+y+1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:

iz &- &w &= &1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\bigg(\frac{1-i}{2},\frac{-1+i}{2}\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer3: The system has $(z,-iz)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer4: The system has $\bigg(\frac{1-i}{2},\frac{1+i}{2}\bigg)$ as unique solution.

question:
Find the solution of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &0 \\ 
&3x &- &y &- &5z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer3:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$(3+z,2-2z,z),\, \forall z\in \mathbb{R}$$.
answer4:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameter:
$$(3+z+y,y,z),\, \forall y,z\in \mathbb{R}$$.

$\left(-1,1,-3\right)$ is the point of minimum and
$\left(1,-1,3\right)$ is the point of maximum.

answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

question:
A consulting firm will carry out two types of projects ($A$ and $B$). The development cost per project $A$ and $B$ is, respectively, $1$ and $2$ monetary units. The requirements in terms of analysts, programmers and terminals for each type of project, are indicated in the following table:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Project} & \text{N. of programmers}  & \text{N. of analysts}  & \text{N. of terminals} \\
\hline
\text{A} & 2 & 2 & 3 \\
\text{B} & 3 & 6 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

The company wants to minimize the cost of developing projects in the next period. In the development of these projects, at least $10$ programmers and $5$ analysts should be used while the company only has $6$ terminals available. In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the company's activity?
answer1: $x_{i}$ is the number of developed project $i$ ($i=1$, for project $A$ and $i=2$, for project $B$)
answer2: $x_{2}$ is the number of developed projects $B$
answer3: $x_{1}$ is the number of developed projects $A$
answer4: $x$ is the number of developed projects $A$ and $B$

question: Which matrix has linearly dependent rows?

answer1: $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} \big( x,y \big)=2x y, \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} \big( x,y \big)=x^2+\cos(y)$
answer2: $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} \big( x,y \big)=2x y, \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} \big( x,y \big)=x^2+ \sin(y)$
answer3: $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} \big( x,y \big)=2x^2y,\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} \big( x,y \big)=x^2+\cos(y)$
answer4: $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x} \big( x,y \big)=2xy, \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y} \big( x,y \big)=x^2-\cos(y)$

question: Medical researchers analyze how different dosages of a drug affect the duration of relief from allergic symptoms. They want to develop a statistical model to predict the time of relief (in days) based on the dosage of a new drug. Identify the predictor variable and the response variable.
answer1: The predictor variable is a dosage of a new drug; the response variable is the time of relief.
answer2: The predictor variable is the time of relief; the response variable is the dosage of the new drug.
answer3: The predictor variable is the mean of time of relief; the response variable is the mean of dosage of the new drug.
answer4: The predictor variable is the mean of dosage of a new drug; the response variable is the mean of time of relief.

question: Identify the Product Rule

Find the general solution for the differential equation system

$\begin{cases}
x'(t)=2x+y \\
y'(t)=x+3y-z \\
z'(t)=-x+2y+3z
\end{cases}$
answer3:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{3t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(3\cos (t)-\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+2C_{2}e^{3t}\cos t+3C_{3}e^{3t}\sin t,
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{t}(\cos (t)-3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(3\cos (t)+\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+5C_{2}e^{t}\cos (t)+5C_{3}e^{t}\sin (t),
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.

Consider the differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x,y,z)=x^{2}yz-\cos \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}.$ Find $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}.$
answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

The Omega Manufacturing Company has discontinued the production of a certain unprofitable product line. This act created considerable excess production capacity. Management is considering devoting this excess capacity to one or more of three products; call them products 1, 2, and 3. The available capacity on the machines that might limit output is summarized in the following table:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|c|c|}
			\hline
			\text{Machine Type} & \text{Available Time (machine hours per week)} \\
			\hline
			\text{Milling machine} & 500 \\
			\text{Lathe} & 350 \\
			\text{Grinder} & 150 \\
			\hline
			\end{array}\]
	
The number of machine hours required for each unit for a given product is the following:
	
		\[\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
			\hline
			\text{Machine Type} & \text{Product 1} & \text{Product 2} & \text{Product 3} \\
			\hline
			\text{Milling machine} & 9 & 3 & 5 \\
			\text{Lathe} & 5 & 4 & 0 \\
		\text{Grinder} & 3 & 0 & 2 \\
			\hline
		\end{array}\]
	
	The sales department indicates that the sales potential for products 1 and 2 exceeds the maximum production rate and the sales potential for product 3 is 20 units per week. The unit profit would be 50?, 20?, and 25? for products 1, 2, and 3, respectively. The objective is to determine how much of each product the company should produce to maximize the profit. Formulate a linear programming model for this problem, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of units of product $i~(i = 1~to~3)$ produced.

The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.
	
In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the company's activity?
answer1: $x_{i}$ the number of units of product $i$ produced ($i=1$, for product $A$ and $i=2$, for product $B$).
answer2: $x$ the number of units of product $1$ and $2$ produced.
answer3: $x_{1}$ is the number of units of product $1$ produced.
answer4: $x_{2}$ is the number of units of product $2$ produced.

Find the conditional extrema of the function $f(x,y)=x^2+y^2-x-y$ having the constraint $x+y=1.$
answer1: The problem has the minimizer $\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right),$ the minimum value of the function being $-\frac{1}{2}.$
answer2: There are two minimizers $\left(\frac{1}{4}, \frac{3}{4}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{3}{4},\frac{1}{4}\right)$ where the minimum value of the function is $-\frac{3}{8}.$
answer3: There are two maximizers $\left(\frac{2}{5}, \frac{3}{5}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{3}{5},\frac{2}{5}\right)$ where the maximum value of the function is $-\frac{12}{25}.$
answer4: The problem has no extrema corresponding to this constraint.

Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{C}^2\right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
(1+i)z& + & (1-i)w & = & i \\
(1-i)z& + & (1+i)w & = & 1-i
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The unique solution of the linear system is $\bigg(\frac{3+i}{4},-\frac{1+i}{4}\bigg)$.
answer2: The solutions of the linear system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{1+i}{4},\frac{-1+i}{4}+z\bigg)$, for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has the vector $(i,-i)$ has its unique solution.

^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x^{2}\right) f(x,y),%

^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}\left( x,y\right) =\left( 2a+4a^{2}x\right) f(x,y),%

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
-x & + & y & + & z & = & a \\
&  & y & + & 3z & = & b \\
x &  &  & + & z & = & c
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every value of $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(a-b+2c,\,3a-2b+3c,\,-a+b-c\right)$.
answer3:
The system has no solution for $a\neq 0$. 
If $a=0$ and for every value of $b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(2c-b,\,3c-2b,\,b-c\right)$.
answer4: For every value of $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has $\left(1,\,1,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline
%& \multicolumn{2}{c|}{Grams of ingredient per serving} &\\
\text{Ingredient} & \text{Steak (gr. per serving)} & \text{Potatoes (gr. per serving)} & \text{Daily Requirements (gr.)} \\
\hline
\text{Carbohydrates} & 5 & 15 & \geq 50 \\
\text{Protein} & 20 & 5 & \geq 40 \\
\text{Fat} & 15 & 2 & \leq 60 \\
\hline
\text{Cost per serving} & 4 & 2 &  \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the Ralph's diet?
answer1: $x_{i}$ is the number of daily servings of food $i$ ($i=1$, for steak and $i=2$, for potatoes)

answer4: $x_{2}$ is the number of daily servings of steak

\end{cases}$$

answer2: The linear system has $\left(4,\,2,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.

Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{C}^2\right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
(1+i)z& + & (1-i)w & = & i \\
(1-i)z& + & (1+i)w & = & 1-i
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The unique solution of the linear system is $\bigg(\frac{3+i}{4},-\frac{1+i}{4}\bigg)$.
answer2: The solutions of the linear system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{1+i}{4},\frac{-1+i}{4}+z\bigg)$, for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has the vector $(i,-i)$ has its unique solution.

2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
x & + & y & - & z & + & w & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.

answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x+y,\,x-y-1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

\end{cases}$$
answer1: The unique solution of the linear system is $\bigg(\frac{3+i}{4},-\frac{1+i}{4}\bigg)$.
answer2: The solutions of the linear system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{1+i}{4},\frac{-1+i}{4}+z\bigg)$, for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.

Letting $j := e^{\frac{2i\pi}{3}}$, find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & - & z & = & 0 \\ 
x & + & jy & + & j^{2}z & = & a \\ 
 &  & j^{2}y & + & jz & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a+b\neq 0$. 

If $b=-a$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{C}$ the system has $\left(\frac{a+(1+2j)z}{1+j},\,\frac{a+jz}{1+j},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer2: The system has no solution for every value of $a$ and $b$.
answer3: The system has $\left(0,0,0\right)$ as its unique solution if $a=b=0$, and for all other values of $a$ and $b$ the system has no solutions.
answer4: For every $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$ the system has $\left(\frac{a+(1+2j)z}{1+j},\,\frac{a+jz}{1+j},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.

\end{cases}$$

Find the general solution for the differential equation system

$\begin{cases}
x'(t)=2x+y \\
y'(t)=x+3y-z \\
z'(t)=-x+2y+3z
\end{cases}$
answer3:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{3t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(3\cos (t)-\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+2C_{2}e^{3t}\cos t+3C_{3}e^{3t}\sin t,
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{t}(\cos (t)-3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(3\cos (t)+\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+5C_{2}e^{t}\cos (t)+5C_{3}e^{t}\sin (t),
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.

\end{cases}$$

Consider the differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x,y,z)=x^{2}yz-\cos \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}.$ Find $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}.$
answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

question: Consider the linear transformation $F:\mathbb{R}^2 \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^2$, such that $F(x, y)=(x+2y, 2x+3y)$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(-3x+2y, 2x-y)$.
answer3: $F^{-1}$ is defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, -2x+y)$ and is not a symmetric operator.
answer4: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, 2x-y)$.

The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.
	
In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the company's activity?
answer1: $x_{i}$ the number of units of product $i$ produced ($i=1$, for product $A$ and $i=2$, for product $B$).
answer2: $x$ the number of units of product $1$ and $2$ produced.
answer3: $x_{1}$ is the number of units of product $1$ produced.
answer4: $x_{2}$ is the number of units of product $2$ produced.

Ralph Edmund loves steaks and potatoes. Therefore, he has decided to go on a steady diet of only these two foods (plus some liquids and vitamin supplements) for all his meals. Ralph realizes that this isn't the healthiest diet, so he wants to make sure that he eats the right quantities of the two foods to satisfy some key nutritional requirements. He has obtained the following nutritional and cost information:

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline
%& \multicolumn{2}{c|}{Grams of ingredient per serving} &\\
\text{Ingredient} & \text{Steak (gr. per serving)} & \text{Potatoes (gr. per serving)} & \text{Daily Requirements (gr.)} \\
\hline
\text{Carbohydrates} & 5 & 15 & \geq 50 \\
\text{Protein} & 20 & 5 & \geq 40 \\
\text{Fat} & 15 & 2 & \leq 60 \\
\hline
\text{Cost per serving} & 4 & 2 &  \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the Ralph's diet?
answer1: $x_{i}$ is the number of daily servings of food $i$ ($i=1$, for steak and $i=2$, for potatoes)
answer2: $x$ is the number of daily servings of food
answer3: $x_{1}$ is the number of daily servings of potatoes
answer4: $x_{2}$ is the number of daily servings of steak

\end{cases}$$

question:
Find the solution of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x_1 &- &x_2 &- &3x_3 &+ &4x_4 &= &1 \\
&x_1 &+ &x_2 &+ &x_3 &+ &2x_4 &= &-1 \\
& &- &x_2 &- &2x_3 &+ &x_4 &= &1 \\
&x_1 &+ &2x_2 &+ &3x_3 &+ &x_4 &= &-2
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$(x_3-3x_4,-1-2x_3+x_4, x_3, x_4), \, \forall x_3,x_4\in\mathbb{R}$$
answer3:
The system has many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$(1-3x_4,-1+x_4, 1, x_4), \, \forall x_4\in\mathbb{R}$$.

question:
The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.

How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning of the company's activity?
answer1:
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
	        & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			& x_{2}\leq 60\\
			&  x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
			    & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\leq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
    			& 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\geq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]

question:
Consider the function $f:\mathbb{R}^{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ given by

$$f(x,y):=\begin{cases}
xy\dfrac{x^2-y^2}{x^2+y^2} & \text{if } (x,y)=(0,0) \\
0 & \text{if } (x,y) = (0,0)
\end{cases}$$

Calculate the second order derivatives at $(0,0)$ and establish if they are equal.
answer1: $1 = \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y}(0,0) \neq \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}(0,0) = -1$.
answer2: $\dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y}(0,0) = \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}(0,0) = -1$.
answer3: $\dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y}(0,0) = \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}(0,0) = 1$.
answer4: $\dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y}(0,0) = \dfrac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}(0,0)=0$.

question:

&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &-1 \\ 
&x &+ &y &- &5z &= &2
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3},y, -\frac{1}{3}\right),\, \forall y\in\mathbb{R}$$.
answer2:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3}z,y, z\right),\, \forall y,z\in\mathbb{R}$$.

Solve the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & + & w & = & -2 \\
3x & - & y & - & 2z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
4x & + & y & - & 5z & - & 3w & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x-y,\,x+y+1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & 2z & = & 2 \\
3x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
-x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(-1,\,3,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has two solutions, $\left(-1,\,3,\,3\right)$ and $\left(2,\,1,\,0\right)$.
answer4: The system has an infinite number of solutions, which are of the form $\left(-4+z,\,z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question: Consider the vectors of $\mathbb{R}^3$, $v_1=(2, 0, 1)$, $v_2=(1, -1, 3)$, $v_3=(1, 1, -2)$ and $v_4=(3, 1, 0)$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: The set $\{v_1, v_2, v_3\}$ is linearly dependent but $\{v_1, v_2, v_4\}$ is linearly independent.
answer2: $v_4$ is a linear combination of $v_1$ and $v_3$
answer3: The space generated by $\{v_1, v_2, v_3\}$ is $\mathbb{R}^3$
answer4: $v_3$ is a linear combination of $v_2$ and $v_4$

question: Consider the differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x,y,z)=x^{2}yz-\cos \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}.$ Find $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}.$
answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
3x & - & y & - & 2z & = & a \\
-x & + & 3y & - & z & = & b \\
-2x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
x & - & 3y & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a \neq 1$ and $b \neq -1$.
If $a=1$ and $b=-1$, then the system has $\left(\frac{2+7z}{8},\,\frac{-2+5z}{8},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,1,\,0\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4:
The system has no solution if $a\neq 1$ and $b\neq 1$. 
If $a=b=1$, the system has $\left(1+y,\,y,\,\frac{3+y}{4}\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

\end{cases}$$

answer3: The system has $\left(-4,3,2\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(-2z+y,y,z\right)$ as solution for every $y,z\in\mathbb{R}$.

The number of nurses required during the day is as follows:

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|}
\hline
\text{Day period} & \text{Required number of nurses} \\
\hline
\text{8:00 a.m. to 12:00 a.m.} & 140 \\
\text{12:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.} & 120 \\
\text{4:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.} & 160 \\
\text{8:00 p.m. to 12:00 p.m.} & 90 \\
\text{12:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m.} & 30 \\
\text{4:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m.} & 60 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model to allow planning the nursing staff.
answer1: None of the options given are correct
answer2: $x$ is the number of nurses working in each shift
answer3: $x_1$, $x_2$, $x_3$ is the number of nurses working in shift $1,~2$ and $3$, respectively
answer4: $x_4$, $x_5$, $x_6$ is the number of nurses working in shift $4,~5$ and $6$, respectively

For each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, describe the solutions of the linear system
$$\begin{cases}
3x & + & y & - & z & = & 1 \\
x & - & 2y & - & z & = & m \\
x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
For $m=-2$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m \neq -2$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer2: The linear system has no solution for every $m\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
For $m \in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m=0$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(0,\,1,\,1\right)$.
For $m \not\in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has a unique solution for each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, which is $\left(0,\,m,\,m-1\right)$.

$$\begin{cases}
2x &  &  &+ &4z &= &0 \\ 
3x &- &4y &+ &12z &= &0 \\ 
x &- &2y &+ &5z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(-2z,\,\frac{3z}{2},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(-4,3,2\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(-2z+y,y,z\right)$ as solution for every $y,z\in\mathbb{R}$.

answer1: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(-1, -1, 0)$ and is normal to the vector $n=(-4, 6, -2)$.
answer2: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(1, 1, 0)$ and is parallel to the vector $n=(2, 3, 1)$.
answer3: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(1, 1, 1)$ and is normal to the vector $n=(2, -3, 1)$.
answer4: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(1, -1, 0)$ and is parallel to the vector $n=(2, -3, 1)$.

question: Consider a right-angled triangle, where the hypotenuse and one side measure 10 cm and 6 cm in length, respectively. Indicate the length of the other side.

Medical researchers analyze how different dosages of a drug affect the duration of relief from allergic symptoms. They want to develop a statistical model to predict the time of relief (in days) based on the dosage of a new drug. Identify the predictor variable and the response variable.
answer1: The predictor variable is a dosage of a new drug; the response variable is the time of relief.
answer2: The predictor variable is the time of relief; the response variable is the dosage of the new drug.
answer3: The predictor variable is the mean of time of relief; the response variable is the mean of dosage of the new drug.
answer4: The predictor variable is the mean of dosage of a new drug; the response variable is the mean of time of relief.

Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{R}^{2} \right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x &- &y &+ &z &+ &2t &= &2 \\
2x &+ &3y &+ &7z &+ &4t &= &-1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(1-2z-2t,\,-1-z,\,z,\,t\right)$ as solution for every $z,t\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1-2z,\,-1-z,\,z,\,0\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(1,-1,0,0\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:

$$\begin{cases}
-x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\
x &+ &3y &- &z &= &0
\end{cases}$$

answer4: The system has $(0,y,y)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Consider the linear applications 

$\begin{array}{cccc}
F: & \mathbb{R}^3 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y, z) & \longrightarrow & (y, x-z)
\end{array}$
$\begin{array}{cccc}
G: & \mathbb{R}^2 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y) & \longrightarrow & (x+y, x-2y)
\end{array}$

Choose the right answer:
answer1: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)$ does not exist
answer2: $(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$and $(G\circ F)$ does not exist
answer3: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$
answer4: $(G\circ F)(y, x-z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)(x, y)=(x+y, x-2y)$

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & y & - & 3z & + & 2t & = & 1 \\
2x & - & y & - & z & + & t & = & 0 \\
x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},\frac{1}{4}t-\frac{7}{12},\frac{3}{4}t-\frac{3}{4},t\bigg)$, for all $t\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},-\frac{7}{12},-\frac{3}{4},0\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer4: The solution of the system is the vector of coordinates $(2,-1,0,0)$.

question:
Use the sample below to choose the correct statement.

$\begin{array}{ |c|c|} 
\hline
\text{Number of children}&\text{Frequency}  \\ 
\hline
0 & 10 \\
1 & 13 \\
2 & 24 \\
3 & 12 \\
4 & 8\\
5 & 2 \\
6 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}$
answer1: The lower quartile is $1$, the upper quartile is $3$, and the median is $2$.
answer2: The lower quartile is $0$, the upper quartile is $6$, and the median is $3$.
answer3: The lower quartile is $10$, the upper quartile is $1$, and the median is $12$.
answer4: The lower quartile is $1$, the upper quartile is $3$, and the median is $1$.
